utterances: The Fatah movement is facing a challenge not only from Barghouti and Juma but from the Islamist Hamas movement, which is fielding candidates for the first time.
Hamas has chosen professional men--doctors, lawyers, engineers--who are known for their honesty.
Juma says Palestinians on the street are tired of government corruption.
He says popular leaders, like Barghouti and himself, offer an alternative to both Fatah and Hamas.
Linda Gradstein, NPR News.
From NPR News, it's ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Michele Norris.
It's the season for all things orange and golden and scarlet.
Think pumpkins, Indian corn and squash.
It's also the high season for apple.
And that makes master baker Dorie Greenspan very happy.
I always peel the apples.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
What I usually do is I peel them and end up eating the peel.
I'm always surprised there's nothing to throw out.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG ""SHOO FLY PIE & APPLE PAN DOWDY"")
(Singing) Shoo fly pie and apple pan dowdy makes your eyes light up, your tummy say howdy.
Shoo fly pie and apple pan dowdy.
I never get enough of that wonderful stuff.
Dorie Greenspan had me doing all kinds of stuff last week, working in my own kitchen.
Peeling, coring and quartering a mess of fresh, Fuji apples.
Dorie is the author of ""Baking: From My Home to Yours."" And for the past year, she's been helping me master ever more difficult recipes.
Let's go to the stove.
Get some heat under them.
And melt the butter.
On today's agenda, Tarte Tatin.
It's sort of like an apple pan dowdy or a cobbler, except it's French and it's the terror of many a home baker.
(SOUNDBITE OF SKILLET HITTING)
Finn did chase that bat down.
Way to stay paws-itive (ph), Finn.
I do know that many stores, many retailers, are blaming the customer instead of looking inwardly and saying, what's wrong?

So when I talk to retailers, I hear them say, well, the customer does this or the customer is coming in with a lot of wrong information or I just don't understand the customer or they're always buying online.
And I think it would be retail 101 to say don't get angry at your customer if they're not shopping in your store.
Maybe look at yourself.
And so what do you think will happen next?
I mean, De Beers isn't doing very well.
And, you know, a lot of retail stores are closing.
There are several things that have to happen.
I can't tell you what will happen.

But in order for the diamond industry to find some sense of balance, it's going to need to understand that its customer today is not the same as its customer 20 years ago and that it's going to need to start meeting its customer where the customer is.
That means online.
And it also means saying, we understand that this is what you're looking for and not we're going to force you to look at the things we have available.
Do you have a diamond ring?
I do not.
(Laughter) That answer surprised me.
That was Lara Ewen.
Her article on diamonds is called ""Rock Bottom: Tracing The Decline In Diamond Retail."" Thank you very much.
Thank you.
The federal government has doled out about half of the $700 billion in bailout money.
Questions remain, though, about what those banks are doing with all that money.
With us now is Henry Blodget.
He's the CEO of the Web site Clusterstock.com.
Now, Henry, some of these banks have received lots and lots of that bailout money.
I think JPMorgan Chase received some $25 billion in bailout money.
So, what are they doing with it?
Wouldn't you like to know?
I would.
(Soundbite of laughter)
They are being very, very discreet, and they're not telling anybody anything.
And I think the usual conclusion from that is that they're not doing things with it that we would be pleased about.
One of the things that they appear to have done with it is pay out $1.6 billion in bonuses and other benefits to executives, which obviously is not something that would have gone over very well.
From the banks' perspective, obviously, they will say, hey, wait a minute.
We don't put the taxpayer money in a particular bucket and then use that to make certain things.
It just all goes into a big cash bucket, and obviously, we have to pay our people.
But no, we're not going to give you details on that or anything else even though it's your money.
But they are supposed to use it, or at least the intent of the legislation was for them to use it, to loosen the credit squeeze, to ease up credit and to lend to one another.
That's right.
It was - the intention was to give them a bigger pot of capital so that they wouldn't be so worried about their assets going bad that they had to keep every bit of cash they had.

What has subsequently been made obvious is that banks are still justifiably very worried that a lot of the assets they have on their books in the form of credit-card loans and student loans and car loans and mortgages, obviously, are still going south at an alarming rate.

And inside, in the quiet rooms at the bank, you can certainly imagine them discussing this and saying hey, we would be crazy to put even more money out there, especially to people who can't afford to pay it back, but most importantly, because we've got to keep it and hoard it and make sure that we're going to get through this storm.
Otherwise, it will all be for naught.
Well, is there anyone keeping track, or trying to keep track, of this TARP money?
I know there is a congressional oversight, a watchdog, a panel run by Elizabeth Warren from Harvard.
And is she able to actually find out where this money is going to go?
I think they've been able to find where some of it has gone initially.
It's been much harder to figure out exactly what the banks have done with it.
And I think, again, the banks' position is, look, we don't have to reveal this.
We are public companies, but we don't reveal loan-by-loan data ever; why should we do it now?
I think the thing that changes, fundamentally, the argument is that things got so bad, you mismanaged things so completely that the government had to step in and give you taxpayer money.
And if that doesn't buy the government the right to say, show us your books and tell us exactly what you're doing with this and every other bit of cash that you've got, I don't what does.
To me, that completely changes the equation.
So, what is Henry Paulson saying about this?
Why doesn't he demand an accounting?
I think that the Treasury's view is that if you force this upon the banks, it will make them even less likely to take the money.

And the whole problem with the TARP from the get go was, how do we persuade these banks that are insisting that they are fine - when everybody knows that they're not fine - how do we persuade them to take the money and then start lending it?
And the answer for the biggest banks was Henry Paulson is going to shove it down their throat, whether they want it or not.
And so, that left the banks with some negotiating room to say, hey, we didn't want the money; you gave it to us.
We don't have to tell you what we're doing with it, and so forth.

I think, unfortunately, we will eventually come to the point where the banks, if they are not lending, the government has to go in and basically say, look, we are going to force you to write down the value of all these assets, and yes, that is going to wipe out your shareholders in some cases and hurt your debt holders.
But then we will do that, and then we will put in new money, and then you won't have anything to do anymore but to lend it.
But I think we're still a ways off from that.
Hm.
And there's still half of the bailout money left that they haven't released.
They haven't, although the cries grow louder every day to release it, and presumably, that is high on the agenda of the Obama administration.
And do you think they'll attach strings to that next $350 billion?
And I'm Michele Norris.
Linear measure is it.
A chart showing constellations.
We also need a great big platter that fits over the heavy cast iron skillet, thick oven mitts and, perhaps, some weedies.
Okay.
So we have three quarters of a cup of sugar on top of the bubbling butter.
And now we're going to turn off the heat.
Now, hold up, the weedies don't do in the Tarte Tatin, they go in up because we're going to need some muscle.
A Tarte Tatin is first prepared over a stove.
We melted the butter, added the sugar, and now we have to arrange the first layer of apples in that skillet, like letter Cs with the curve side facing down.
Think about it as pineapple upside down cake, okay?
Wedge at the bottom of the pan will eventually be the top of our dessert.
You can fuss and figure out a pattern, but somehow, no matter what you do, this tarte always looks beautiful.
A bit of history, this is a desert that comes with a wonderful story.
What we know for sure is that there were two sisters in the Loire Valley, the Tatin sisters, and they had an inn where they cooked for their guests.
One of the stories that I've heard, one of the sisters was making an apple tart, and she had put it in the oven when she realized that there was no dough under the apples.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)

And thinking quickly, she had people outside in the dining room and she had things to do in the kitchen, she just took the dough and put it on top of the apples and then flipped it over and served it that way.
And it was evidently so delicious that they continued to make it.
And if you go to the area where the Tatin sisters lived, there are Tarte Tatin societies that get together to their official recipes, their unofficial - it's really a cult sweep.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
Two layers of apples later, the heat's back on.
We stand over the stove, watching and listening till the apples caramelize in that butter-sugar mix.
After about 15 minutes, the bubbles have gotten fatter, the apple sauce in my kitchen smell divine and I am getting hungry.
Okay.
So while we...
